'Cobalt-60', , is a synthetic radioactive isotope of cobalt with a half-life of
5.27 years. It is produced artificially by neutron activation of the isotope
. Malkoske, G. R. [http://www.nuclearfaq.ca/malkoskie_cobalt_paper.pdf Cobalt-
60 production in CANDU power reactors] decays by beta decay to the stable
isotope nickel-60 (). The activated nickel nucleus emits two gamma rays with
energies of 1.17 and 1.33 MeV, hence the overall nuclear equation of the
reaction is

 + n â â + e â + + gamma rays.
